text: Charles Kennedy is duly elected the
leader of the Liberal Democrat Charles
Kennedy was just 39 when he took over
from Paddy Ashdown
he'd entered Parliament sixteen years
earlier I pledge to you today that I'm
going to stand up above all else for
social justice we have to give voice to
the disadvantaged and dispossessed
because those voices are not being held
by New Labour that's for sure Charles
Kennedy was brought up in the Scottish
Highlands in the shadow of been nervous
a home full of music but politics was
his love his father Ian are crafted by
trade composed a special tune when his
youngest son became a social democrat MP
in 1983 a crisis within the SDP soon
catapulted Charles Kennedy to the for
the party that had once vowed to break
the mold of British politics was itself
in trouble Kennedy led the calls for a
merger with a Liberal Party he
negotiated much of the successful deal
and in the process fell out bitterly
with the SDP s leader David Owen with
Paddy Ashdown now at the helm Charles
Kennedy enjoyed his newfound status as
leader in Waiting a love of the odd
tipple coupled with his many television
appearances brought him the nickname
chat show Charlie Charles Cannaday shows
like this did little to bolster his
reputation as a political heavyweight
but brought the one thing all
politicians crave public recognition and
when Ashton stood down in 1999 Charles
Kennedy was a popular choice to succeed
him he had though a very different
relationship with New Labour no more
meetings of the joint Cabinet Committee
instead Charles Kennedy attempted to
reposition the Liberal Democrats as a
radical independent third force in
British politics the Liberal Democrats
are nobodies poodles but we're not
Rottweilers either we don't savage on
common
that's the old politics more Lib Dem MPs
joined the Commons after the 2001
election and two years later another
coup the capture of Brent East in a
by-election fairer higher taxation and
more public spending remained the
policies joining the single currency a
key aspiration but some hallowed Lib Dem
dreams were jettisoned Kennedy
dismissing proportional representation
as unachievable and he risked isolating
his party when he led the attacks on
Tony Blair every rack every measure of
public opinion does show that people are
not persuaded as to the case for the
course of action being followed now why
does the plaintiff mister think that
remains the situation yeah thank you
very much but Charles Kennedy stamina
for the fight started to be questioned
his gaunt appearance at the Lib Dem
Spring Conference in 2004 shocked
commentators he'd lost weight he was
sweating profusely with his unique style
and personality
he'd steered his party to its greatest
electoral success but many will regret
the potential Charles Kennedy showed in
his early groundbreaking days remained
unfulfilled
